The Fine Art of Farce

By James Bithell

Renowned journalist, playwright and novelist Michael Frayn is one of York's recent honorary degree recipients. Chris Owen chats to the man of many talents about student life, Sylvia Plath and the fine art of farce.

Review: Macbeth

Drama Barn excel in their ultra-cool performance of Macbeth. Joseph D'angelo reviews.

Review: The Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde

Theatre Mill's perofrmance of The Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde is evocative, immersing you within its Victorian world. Lily Papworth reviews.

Classics are the New Black

Penguin have recently released a new set of affordable and accessible classics - The Little Black Classics range. But do such iconic texts need to be made more accessible? Can these 'new' texts still be considered classics? Zoe Thomson considers the impact of Penguin's new endeavour.

Review: South Pacific

Although a seemingly promising production, York Light Opera's South Pacific turned out to be rather disappointing. Ashley Reed reviews.

Review: Double Take - La Dispute and Les Acteurs

For their latest show, the TFTV department have decided to tackle not one but two plays from 18th century French dramatist Marivaux. Translated by J. Murray and adapted by the dramaturg team, the production provided an ample opportunity to witness seldom-performed examples of classic romantic enlightenment comedy. Ricky Jones reviews.

Review: Uncle Vanya

Although a play about boredom, Uncle Vanya is highly entertaining as well as rather touching. Ayomide Sanwo reviews.

So Long, Page 3

Fringe success Josie Long chats to Grace Marsh about Edinburgh's infamous comedy festival, Twitter and Page 3

The Shock Market

Joel Down considers whether pieces of art still have the capacity to shock their audience.

Ask the Editors: Marcus Lyon's 'mankind on the move'

Photographer Marcus Lyon presents his vision of a claustropobic future. Jaz Hayward and Lara Swan discuss 'Exodus: migrations, megacities and mankind on the move'

Review: Abigail's Party

Drama Soc's performance of Abigail's Party is certainly a hit, combining the feel of the gaudy 70's with some unique and entertaining characters. Ashley Reed reviews.

Review: Cara Josephine

Holly Woolnough reviews Josie Long's new show, Cara Josephine, at the Duchess. Promising hilarity and heartbreak, Long certainly lived up to expectations.

Sugar, Spice and Not Everything's Nice

19 year-old photography student, Hannah Altman, releases a photographic series criticising the unrealistic portrayals of women in the media. Lara Shannon considers the significance of Altman's work and its instant popularity online.

Review: Antony and Cleopatra

In aid of York Theatre Royal's re-development project, actors both local and renowned stage a rehearsed reading of Shakespeare's Antony and Cleopatra. Daniel Bowen reviews.

York: a UNESCO City of Media Arts

As York wins the accolade of a UNESCO City of Media Arts, Angelica Curzi considers what the title really means and what's in store for the city over the coming year.

Review: Animal Farm

Staging one of George Orwell's most renowned texts, the Antigone Collective give a simplistic yet engaging performance. Lily Papworth reviews.

Review: Our Country's Good

Dramasoc gives us a gripping performance this week at the Drama Barn that is both harrowing and comical. Lily Papworth reviews.

Review: Spamalot

Bringing all the delight of Monty Python to the stage, Amy Blumsom reviews the fantastically farcical Spamalot at the Grand Opera House

Review: The Witches of Eastwick

CHMS execute their production of The Witches of Eastwick with near-on perfection. Amy Wong reviews.

Review: Calamity Jane

Ayomide Sanwo reviews the classic musical from the Wild West, Calamity Jane

Review: Omid Djalili

Lily Papworth reviews Omid Djalili's show, Iranalamidingdong, at the Grand Opera House.

Review: Cirque Beserk

Perhaps playing too close to the old fashioned circus tropes, Tess Pullen reviews Cirque Beserk at York's Grand Opera House

To Kill a Mockingbird sequel... 55 years on

Is Harper Lee's new novel, Go Set a Watchman, as exciting as first thought? Rosemary Collins considers the reality of To Kill a Mockingbird's sequel

Review: Jezebel

Liam Mullally reviews Dramasoc's engaging and 'intermittently very funny' production of Jezebel

Review: Woman In Mind

Emma Ralph reviews Dramasoc's comcically engaging performance of Woman In Mind.

Storytelling at Say Owt Slam

At York's second Say Owt Slam, Sophia Walker, BBC Scottish National Slam Champion, talks to Tess Pullen about her journey into spoken word poetry and her success.

Review: PantSoc's The Hunchback of Notre Dame

PantSoc's latest endeavour promises hilarity and personality. Deborah Lam has a hunch you'd like it.

Review: Philip Pullman's Grimm Tales

Emma Allden recounts her visit to the Bargehouse's exhibition, Philip Pullman's Grimm Tales, and its enchanting, magical aura.

Daniel Bowen reviews Dramasoc's intimate yet gripping performance of Sartre's No Exit.
